div1.p: Griffitts reports on the breeding of Anopheles in salt water, mainly in Virginia.

div1.head: Report: Anopheles and Sea Water. Observations on the Development of A. quadrimaculatus, A. crucians and a. punctipennis in Salt and Brackish Waters, by T.H.D. Griffitts, [19--]

ANOPHELES AND SEA-WATER
Observations on the Development of A. quadrimaculatus,
A. crucians and A. punctipennis in Salt and Brackish Waters.
By
T.H.D. Griffitts, Epidemiologist,
U.S. Public Health Service.
div1.p:
In connection with the control of malaria in extra-canton-
ment zones located in “tidewater” country and in the course
of other malaria investigations, both extending over a period
of four years, the writer has had occasion to note something
of the relative breeding habits of A. quadrimaculatus, A.
crucians and A. punctipennis in relation to sea-water and di
lutions of sea-water.

As stated by Howard, Dyar and Knab#, “Anopheles have been
found breeding in salt or brackish water in many parts of the
world; in every case the habit has been found restricted to
certain species”. Literature (that available, at least) is si-
lent as to the amount of salinity withstood by the common
North American species of Anopheles. Smith, in speaking of
Anopheles in New Jersey, says of A. quadrimaculatus, “this form
also occurs in brackish water on the salt marshes, hence has
a somewhat wider range [than punctipennis] and adds the pos-
itive danger of disease to the disadvantages of an undrained
marsh”. That A. crucians breeds freely in the brackish marshes
# “The Mosquitoes of North and Central America and the West Indies,” Vol. I, p. 224.
2
is well and generally known, but there appears to be no record
as to the per cent. of sea-water that even this species will
withstand.

The observations herein noted were made in areas bordering
upon either Chesapeake Bay, Hampson Roads (or tidal tributa-
ries) or the Atlantic Ocean at Virginia Beach, Virginia.

(1) Near Langley Field, Hampton, Virginia, in September, 1917,
a heavy A. crucians infestation of barns was found. The pro-
duction area was found to be a salt marsh three-fourths of a
mile away. Subsequent and repeated examinations revealed A.-
crucians breeding (producing) generally in the marsh in water
showing a salinity of 10,086 (Hampton Roads at Newport News,
salinity 10,146). Aedes sollicitans was also breeding pro-
fusely in the same water. The A. crucians larvae were gener-
ally found amongst the salt grass, distichlis spicata, the
smaller and finer of the principal marsh grasses found in this
locality. The larger salt marsh grass, spartina glabra, grows
more abundantly where there is more tidal action, and A. cruc-
ians breeding was found amongst this grass only where growth
was much retarded or where it was dead. No other species of
Anopheles bred in this marsh, although a fresh water pond was
producing A. quadrimaculatus and the fresh water streams near
were producing A. punctipennis.

(2) At Virginia Beach, Virginia, Lake Rudes, originally a ti-
dal stream and salt marsh, is intermittently formed by a de-
posit of sand at the beach, blocking the outlet and impound-
3
ing salt water. With addition of fresh water from small
streams and rainfall the water of the lake becomes propor-
tionately less saline. The grassy borders of this lake were
found at different times from August to October, 1919, to be
breeding A. crucians very freely, larvae of all sizes, or pupae,
were taken at every selective dip. This lake, the salinity of
which had undergone no appreciable change during several weeks,
conformed to Carter's classification of a “complete” breeding
place, i.e., the eggs deposited here hatched and the succeed-
ing stages of larvae and pupae through to the imagos were
completed in the same water. The salinometer reading here was
10,088 (the salinity of the Ocean here was 10,196). Express-
ed, then, in percentage of sea-water at this point, the lake
was 34.6. Here was a body of diluted sea-water covering approx-
imately five acres producing A. crucians, a malaria vector, in
sufficient numbers to be of decided health importance to the
community. Extending to near Lake Rudee and separated there-
from by a strip of elevated land only a few hundred feet wide
was Lake Holly which, with very rare exceptions, was fresh water.
(During the time of observations, the highest salinity was
10,003) This lake was producing A. quadrimaculatus in great
numbers. Was not this a striking contrast in the selective
breeding places of the two species? Lake Rudee, 34.6% sea-
water, Anopheles production 100% Holly, prac-
tically fresh (1.5% sea-water) Anopheles production 100%
quadrimaculatus. The two breeding areas were separated by less
4
600 feet, and in a stable on this strip of land on an early
day in September there were collected 67 A. crucians and 85
A. quadrimaculatus.

(3) At West Point, York River showed a salinity of 10,110. A
pond had been formed by dumpage of rubbish across a salt marsh
for the purpose of extending a street, the fill being very loose
and porous and no culvert was installed. The main tidal stream
was blocked and at high tide additional salt water entered
the pond through the fill. However, the level of the pond
varied little between tides. The salinity at the lower por-
tion of the pond was 10,077, or 70% York River water (This
would be approximately 50% sea-water as generally occuring
along this section of the Atlantic coast). A. crucians was breed-
ing (producing) profusely in this water. Two hundred feet away,
in a different portion of the same body of water, but where
the salinity was only 10,003, due to large amount of seepage
and the lack of mixing of the waters by wave action, A. quad-
rimaculatus was producing freely.

(4) Experiment. A. crucians larvae of all sizes and pupae coll-
ected from obstructed ditches in the marsh of Back River near
Langley Field September 9, 1920 (salinity 10,088), placed in
sea-water, salinity 10,100, on September 10, were not unfavor-
ably affected by the transfer. All but three (these of first
molt when placed in the sea-water) had developed into imagos
within twelve days. Even the smallest of the larvae developed
equally as well in the sea-water as those in the fresh water
control.

(1) Lake Holly, at Virginia Beach, as before stated, is prac-
tically always fresh. Some years ago a flume was constructed
connecting the lake with the ocean for the purpose of admit-
ting sea-water at high tide, In its present condition, salt
water comes into the lake only at times of very high storm
tide; so no success is accomplished in keeping the salinity
even high enough to preclude the breeding of A. quadrimaculatus.
In many parts of the lake, prior to the successful malaria
control operations in 1920, this species was foud breeding
freely. The highest salinity found at any time was 10,003,
or approximately 1,5% sea-water at this place. No other
species of Anopheles was found breeding in this lake at any
time. A. quadrimaculatus was breeding profusely in another
fresh water pond one half mile distant and A. crucians in the
saline Lake Rudee a few hundred feet away.

(2) The small body of impounded water at West Point, previous-
ly noted, covered an area approximately three acres in extent,
in which there was a growth of raeds and salt grass (distich-
lis apicata) still remaining. As noted, the lower saline
portion of the pond was producing A. crucians. On the oppo-
site side of the pond, 200 feet away, where seepage outcrop ren-
dered the water fresh, only A. quadrimaculatus was breeding.
The salinometer reading here was 10,003. The land rises ab-
ruptly from the narrow valley and this topographic condition,
together with the amount of vegetation in the water, served
to prevent wave action and mixing of the waters, and, conse-
6
quently, the water on this side of the pond remained almost en-
tirely fresh.

(3) A pond at the upper end of a salt marsh near Newport
News produced A. quadrimaculatus in great numbers in 1917.
This pond was one of the notorius products of road construc-
tion to be found in tide-water country, where roads are built
across salt marshes: culverts are set at too h high elevation
or are inadequate in capacity, resulting in the impoundment
of fresh or more or less saline water above the fill. In this
particular case, at times of storm tides salt water was ad-
mitted to the fresh water of the pond. However, the salinity
was never so strong or so continuous as to kill the luxurient
growth of cat-tails that occupied practically all of the
two acres of the pond, except a small portion near the efflu-
ent culvert. On an occasion of high tide the lower portion of
the pond showed a salinity of 10,076. At this time breeding
was under control, but the question naturally arises as to
whether or not the larvae and pupae CIA A. quadrimaculatus
may resist a relatively high degree of salinity intermittent-
ly. The determination of this point has a practical bearing
on malaria control and could be trated readily by ex-
periments.

(4) Near Lee Hall and Camp Eustis, Virginia, in 1918, F.E.
Chidester and T.B.Hayne, Jr., working with the writer, collected
Anopheles larvae from the edge of a tidal marsh, the water
showing a salinity of 10,048. Two specimans of acquad-A. quadrimac-
7
ulatus emerged from this collection. Chidester and Hayne
are both careful observers and they expressed the opinion
that this was a complete breeding place. However, in surveys
extending over several seasons, under various conditions and
in many salt marsh areas, the writer has been unable to sub-
stantiate their findings.

(5) Experiment. Fourteen A. quadrimaculatus larvae, all sizes,
collected from a fresh water pond and put into sea-water, sa-
linity 10,160, were all killed within twelve hours, the larger
ones surviving the longest. No mortality in the pond water
control.

The writer has never found breeding of this species, A.
punctipennis, in salt or brackish water, nor is there report
of such breeding. But there is much evidence that A. puncti-
pennis has a wider range of breeding habits than either A.
quadrimaculatus or A. crucians. It is found in the coldest
mountain springs and branches and at times in streams and ditch-
es foul with sewage. It is not resistent, however, to sea-water.
Experiment. Twenty-five A. punctipennis larvae, all sizes, coll-
ected from a ditch and a fresh water lake and transferred to
sea-water, salinity, 10,100, all killed within seven hours. No
mortality in fresh water control.

1. A. crucians was found to breed in sea-water diluted to a
maximum salinity of 10,088, or slightly more than 50% aver-
8
age sea-water. Transferring A. crucians larvae which had
started their development in saline water to sea-water
did not unfavorably affect their subsequent development.

2. A. quadrimaculatus was not found to breediin numbers
to be of importance in a higher salinity than 10,003, or
1.5% sea-water. In one case two larvae found in water with
a salinity of 10,046 developed into A. quadrimaculatus imagos,
but this observation requires confirmation as to whether this species may
complete its entire water cycle in so high a per cent. of
sea-water. The question is raised as to whether A. quadri-
maculatus larvae may not withstand much higher salinity inter-
mittantly then continuously. Specimens of A. quadrimaculatus
larvae transferred from non-saline pond-water to sea-water,
salinity 10,160, were all killed within 12 hours.

3. A. punctipennis was not found breeding in salt or brack-
ish waters. This species breeds under a wider range of con-
ditions than either A. quadrimaculatus or A. crucians, but
apparently does not breed in salt or brackish waters. Lar-
vae of A. punctipennis put into sea-water were all dead with-
in seven hours.
